title: 107_hr3378
content: The "Commission on Homeland Security Act" establishes the Commission on Homeland Security with the duty to fulfill its responsibilities. The Commission on Homeland Security is tasked with studying procedures to protect the security of the United States, including the efficiency of federal departments, adequacy of personnel resources, controls over financial and information systems, accuracy of personal identification information, organizational effectiveness of federal agencies, and relationships between the federal government, states, and municipalities to protect security. The Commission on Homeland Security consists of 21 members appointed by various officials, with expertise in information technology, security, civil liberties, and law enforcement. Members must be appointed within 60 days of the Act's enactment. The Commission on Homeland Security consists of 21 members appointed within 60 days of the Act's enactment. Members serve for life without pay but receive travel expenses. The Chairperson is the Assistant to the President for Homeland Security. SEC. 5. EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR AND STAFF OF COMMISSION; EXPERTS AND CONSULTANTS. The Commission shall have an Executive Director appointed by the Commission, paid at level IV of the Executive Schedule. Additional staff may be appointed and paid as deemed appropriate. The Executive Director and staff may be appointed and paid without following certain civil service laws, with a salary limit of GS-15. The Commission may also procure temporary experts and consultants. The Commission can hire temporary experts and consultants under section 3109(b) of title 5, United States Code. Federal agencies can also detail personnel to assist the Commission on a reimbursable basis. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, and receive evidence as needed. A minimum of eight hearings must be held in various states. Additionally, the Commission is granted additional powers as outlined in Section 7. The Commission is authorized to take actions on behalf of the Commission, obtain necessary information from US departments, and accept gifts or money for its work. The Commission has the authority to issue subpoenas for witnesses and evidence related to investigations, and may use the United States mails for communication. Additionally, the Administrator of General Services can provide administrative support services upon request. The Commission has the authority to issue subpoenas for witnesses and evidence related to investigations within the United States. If a person refuses to obey a subpoena, the Commission can apply to a United States district court for an order requiring that person to appear and testify. Subpoenas of the Commission shall be served in the manner provided for subpoenas issued by a United States district court under the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. Service of process in United States district courts can be done in the judicial district where the person resides or can be found. The Commission is considered a U.S. agency for immunity purposes under title 18 of the United States Code. A person cannot refuse to testify or produce evidence based on self-incrimination, but they cannot be prosecuted for any compelled testimony. A person cannot refuse to testify or produce evidence based on self-incrimination, but they cannot be prosecuted for any compelled testimony. The Commission will submit a report to the President and Congress within 14 months of the Act's enactment, including findings, conclusions, and recommendations. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting the final report. Appropriations are authorized as needed for the Act.
